Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E: Correlated Wavefunction Methods for Gas and Condensed Phases
Award.AbstractNarration:
Emily Carter of Princeton University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods Program to pursue development of accurate and efficient ab initio electronic structure methods for predicting the behavior of large molecules and condensed matter. The Condensed Matter and Materials Theory and the Computational and Data Driven Materials Research programs in the Division of Materials Research and the Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering Program are co-funding this proposal. Carter and coworkers are providing the means to address two grand challenges in science and engineering: (i) accurate evaluation of chemical bond dissociation energies and reaction energetics for large molecules and (ii) accurate description of charge transfer and electronic excited states in condensed phases. Carter's fast correlated wavefunction (CW) methods are being taken to the next level in terms of speed (exploiting scarcity and via parallelization) and functionality (via gradients, nonadiabatic couplings, and transition dipole moments). Her potential-functional-based embedding theory then incorporates her fast CW methods so that, e.g., complex photo-excitation and charge transfer at electrode surfaces can be accurately described.

The methods that the Carter and her multidisciplinary research group are developing can be used to predict the mostly unexplored thermochemical kinetics of combustion reactions involving very large molecules such as biodiesel fuels. This foundational information is critical to determining how to optimize the energy efficiency of renewable fuels. Other methods being developed by this group will furnish fundamental understanding of the chemistry and physics of fuel cells and solar cells, with an eye to improving their energy conversion efficiency as well. Women and under-represented minorities are involved in her research program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes for NSF Grant No. 1265700

CDS&E: Correlated Wavefunction Methods for Gas and Condensed Phases

PI, Emily A. Carter, Princeton University

Chemists and material scientists respectively explore properties of molecules and materials that contribute to our quality of life in profound ways. Understanding the behavior of these different forms of matter enables optimization of all sorts of important processes, from sustainable fuel combustion for transportation and heating to clean electricity production to sunlight-enabled catalytic production of chemicals, among others. However, the associated molecules and materials must be examined at the scale of the atom to gain the insights needed. Measurements at the atomic scale can be made under ideal circumstances but often such experiments are simply not possible with today's technologies. In such cases, computer simulation can help fill the void of knowledge.

To study chemical reactions and materials behavior by computer requires starting from the basic laws governing how electrons are distributed in space and energy, because those electron distributions - the so-called electronic structure - determine everything there is to know about these forms of matter. These basic laws are those of quantum mechanics. During this grant, Emily Carter and her team have derived efficient, accurate quantum mechanics computer simulation techniques that enabled, for example, the first studies of large molecules found in biodiesel fuels and of nanostructured catalysts that, when exposed to sunlight, can break and reform some of the strongest chemical bonds known, so as to facilitate sustainable catalytic production of chemicals.

The Carter group's techniques include ones that express the electronic structure of molecules in terms of truncated wavefunctions - so-called local correlation methods - and include ones that embed wavefunctions in a so-called embedding potential derived within an exact theory known as density functional theory. These embedding theories, pioneered by the Carter group over two decades, allow for accurate treatment of localized phenomena in solids, especially on the surfaces of solids, where chemical catalysis occurs. The Carter group has implemented these theories into software that is publicly available on their github site: https://github.com/EACcodes.

The local correlation methods developed during this grant are described in eight published peer-reviewed articles, with two other articles published using these techniques to study combustion of biofuels. The suite of embedding methods developed during this grant are described in nine published peer-reviewed articles, with one last article recently submitted for publication and three published peer-reviewed articles that apply one of the embedding theories to study charge-transfer catalytic bond breaking of oxygen gas reacting with an aluminum surface and hydrogen gas dissociating on illuminated gold nanoparticle surfaces. The Carter group embedding theories are unique in the world at being able to accurately simulate electron transfer and excited states at metal surfaces, phenomena that are key to understanding electrocatalysis and nanoscale photocatalysis processes that will be fundamental in moving our economy away from fossil-fuel-based thermal processing of chemicals and fuels.

Thirteen young scholars were trained with financial support from this grant: three undergraduates (one of whom was female), three Ph.D. students (two of whom were female), and seven postdoctoral research associates (two of whom were female). Many of these young scientists now are employed in our tech sector, at Facebook, FireEye, ASML Brion, Schroedinger, and Advanced Micro Devices, while others have taken faculty positions at Florida State University, the Technical University of Vienna, and Tsinghua-Berkeley-Shenzhen Institute. As this outcomes report is meant for the public to appreciate, deeper technical details for the expert reader regarding the accomplishments this grant made possible are available upon request.


Last Modified: 11/02/2018
Modified by: Emily A Carter
